misconceptions.name: Submitted Incorrect Program
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem (Q3). This suggests a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment instructions or file submission process.
misconceptions.student_belief: This code fulfills the requirements for the assignment, or I have submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must accurately implement the logic described in the Grade Calculator problem statement, including reading a single grade and using conditional statements to map it to a letter grade.
symptoms: Code calculates distance using Math.sqrt and four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2).
No logic for handling grades (0-100) or letter mapping is present.
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misplaced focus (solving a previously learned or practiced problem) or submitting the wrong file for the assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment instructions carefully and ensure the code you submit directly addresses the requirements of Q3, the Grade Calculator.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code content is entirely dedicated to a geometry calculation, providing no implementation for grading logic.

evidence.note: The class name and input gathering clearly indicate the wrong program was written/submitted.
The core logic calculates distance, which is irrelevant to a grade calculator.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Confusion between Logical AND (&&) and Bitwise AND (&)
misconceptions.description: In a conceptual grading snippet, the student uses the single ampersand bitwise operator (&) to combine two boolean expressions, instead of the standard logical short-circuit operator (&&).
misconceptions.student_belief: The single ampersand (&) and the double ampersand (&&) are interchangeable when combining boolean conditions.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The logical short-circuit AND (&&) is preferred for combining boolean expressions, as it only evaluates the second operand if the first is true. The single ampersand (&) is the non-short-circuiting bitwise AND operator, which, while functional on booleans, is less efficient and is primarily intended for bit manipulation.
symptoms: Usage of single '&' within an 'if' condition.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the difference between logical operators and their bitwise counterparts, possibly due to other languages or C-style origins where '&' might be used differently.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use '&&' (double ampersand) for combining standard conditional checks like variable ranges. Reserve '&' for specific operations on integers (bitwise manipulation).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The usage is explicit in a self-contained test snippet, indicating the student was trying to confirm that operator's behavior or believes it is correct.

evidence.note: The use of single '&' for conditional flow control.

misconceptions.name: Complete task misalignment - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves a distance calculation problem (computing distance between two 2D points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. This demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that this submission addresses the grade calculator requirement, or has submitted code from a different assignment entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F). The submitted code reads two coordinate pairs and calculates Euclidean distance instead.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'Enter x1 and y1' instead of 'Enter grade'
Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer grade
Program calculates distance using Math.sqrt formula instead of comparing grade ranges
Output shows distance instead of letter grade
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of something like 'GradeCalculator'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either submitted the wrong file, copy-pasted from a previous assignment, or has misunderstood the problem statement entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh with the grade calculator problem. Read a single integer grade, then use if-else statements to check ranges (90-100 for A, 80-89 for B, etc.) and output the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty that this is the wrong problem. The code demonstrates competent programming for the distance problem but fails to address any aspect of the grade calculator requirements.

evidence.note: Code solicits x1 and y1 coordinates, which has nothing to do with grade input

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
		System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Calculates Euclidean distance instead of mapping grade to letter

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Use of bitwise AND instead of logical AND
misconceptions.description: The student uses a single ampersand (&) instead of double ampersand (&&) for logical comparison. While this code snippet appears to be labeled as 'Debug/conceptual example', it demonstrates confusion about the difference between bitwise AND and logical AND operators.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that a single & can be used interchangeably with && for boolean conditions, or doesn't understand the distinction between bitwise and logical operations.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, && is the logical AND operator used for boolean conditions. The & operator is bitwise AND, which operates on individual bits of integer values. For conditional logic, always use &&.
symptoms: Single & used in if condition instead of &&
Code may produce unexpected behavior if operands are integers rather than booleans
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators (used for bit manipulation) and logical operators (used for boolean conditions). The student may not have internalized when to use each operator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the single & with && in boolean conditions. The pattern should be: if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90) for proper logical AND.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This appears in a debug/example section of the code rather than the main logic, but it still demonstrates the misconception. The comment suggests the student was intentionally testing this, which could indicate awareness or misunderstanding. The pattern is clear enough to flag as a probable misconception.

evidence.note: Single & used instead of && in boolean condition. Comment acknowledges 'single &' but doesn't clarify if this is intentional testing or a misconception.

misconceptions.name: Hard-coding the grade instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: The program uses a fixed integer value for the grade rather than reading the grade value from the user, even though a Scanner is already being used for other inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can just assign a value like 85 to the grade variable directly instead of reading the user's actual grade from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read the numeric grade from the user via the Scanner (e.g., using nextInt or nextDouble). Hard-coding a value means the program cannot respond to different user inputs.
symptoms: The program never prompts the user to enter a grade.
The grade variable is assigned a literal value (85) instead of using input.nextInt().
The program will always behave as if the user entered 85, regardless of any input.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between using variables to store dynamic user input versus using them to store fixed test values; the student may be used to testing with literals and not realize that the assignment requires interactive input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded grade assignment with a prompt and a Scanner read, e.g., System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();
related_concepts: Difference between literals and user-provided values
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student correctly uses Scanner for other values (x1, y1, x2, y2) but does not use it for grade; instead, they assign grade = 85 directly, which strongly suggests they do not see that the grade must come from input.

evidence.note: Scanner is used properly for x1, y1, etc., but the grade is set with a hard-coded literal (85) instead of being read from input.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Solving a different problem instead of implementing the grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The submission primarily computes the distance between two points and prints that distance. It does not implement the required mapping from numeric grades to letter grades or the specified output format.
misconceptions.student_belief: Including some conditional logic around a grade variable inside my existing distance-between-points program is sufficient for the grade-calculator question, even if I do not actually map all grade ranges to letter outputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program for this question should focus on reading a numeric grade (0–100), using conditionals to classify it into A/B/C/D/F based on the given ranges, and printing the corresponding letter grade, matching the problem's sample run.
symptoms: The main logic computes dx, dy, and the Euclidean distance between two points instead of processing grades.
There is no code that maps grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.) to letter grades.
There is no output of the form "Letter grade: X".
Only a single conditional on grade (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) appears, and it prints a debug message rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have reused a previous lab or example (distance between points) and appended a small conditional snippet, without restructuring the program to actually solve the specified grade-calculator problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start a fresh main method for this question that only does what the problem asks: prompt for a grade, read it, use an if/else-if/else chain to check each range, and print the correct letter grade (A–F) in the required format.
related_concepts: Designing program structure around a single task
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The majority of the code is a distance-between-points example, and there is no implementation of the grade-to-letter mapping or the required output. This is clear evidence that the problem requirements were not followed.

evidence.note: The class and main method implement distance computation and only include a small debug conditional on grade; there is no grade classification into letters or the required "Letter grade:" output.

misconceptions.name: Solved Wrong Problem Entirely
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points instead of writing the requested Grade Calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the provided code fulfills the requirements of the Q3 Grade Calculator assignment, or perhaps they accidentally submitted code for a different assignment (Distance Between Points).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade and using conditional logic (if/else) to determine and print a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F). The current code implements a geometric calculation.
symptoms: Program input relates to coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
Program output displays a distance, not a letter grade.
Code structure (class name, input variables, calculation) is completely unrelated to the task description.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment requirements, submitting the wrong file, or poor file management resulting in execution of unrelated code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the program from scratch focusing only on the Q3 requirements: read one integer, use if/else branching, and print one character (the letter grade).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code calculates distance, not grade. This is self-evident and affects every single rubric point.

evidence.note: The entire program implements 'Distance Between Points' instead of 'Grade Calculator'.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using Bitwise AND for Logical Operations
misconceptions.description: The student uses the bitwise AND operator (`&`) instead of the short-circuit logical AND operator (`&&`) within a conditional statement testing boolean ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the single ampersand operator (`&`) is the standard way to combine boolean conditions, or perhaps they are unaware of the distinction between `&` (bitwise) and `&&` (logical/short-circuit).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For combining boolean expressions in conditional logic, Java encourages the use of `&&` (short-circuit logical AND). While `&` works for boolean types, it forces evaluation of both sides, which is less efficient and is primarily intended for bit manipulation on integers.
symptoms: Potential performance impact (minor) if the first condition is false.
Incorrect operator usage for boolean logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between logical operators (`&&`, `||`) and bitwise operators (`&`, `|`), possibly due to visual similarity or lack of instruction emphasizing the short-circuit behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use the double ampersand (`&&`) when combining boolean logical conditions (like `grade >= 80 && grade < 90`). Reserve the single ampersand (`&`) for bit manipulation on integer types.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student explicitly uses `&` in the sample conditional code snippet.

evidence.note: The student uses '&' (bitwise AND) to combine boolean expressions, rather than '&&' (logical AND).

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using single bitwise AND (&) instead of logical AND (&&) in boolean conditions
misconceptions.description: Student uses the single & operator in a boolean conditional expression where the && (logical AND) operator should be used. The & operator performs bitwise AND on integers, not boolean logic evaluation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that & can be used interchangeably with && when combining boolean conditions in an if statement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, && is the logical AND operator for evaluating boolean expressions in conditionals. & is the bitwise AND operator for binary operations on integer values. In boolean contexts, always use && for logical AND operations.
symptoms: Incorrect operator used in conditional: grade >= 80 & grade < 90
Line comment explicitly states 'using single &', suggesting confusion about operator functionality
Code may produce unexpected results depending on integer value interpretation
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators (used on integer bits) and logical operators (used on boolean values). Student may not understand that & and && have fundamentally different purposes in Java.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace all single & operators with && when writing boolean conditions. Use & only for bitwise operations on integers, not for combining boolean expressions. Test: grade >= 80 && grade < 90
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Direct evidence: the code explicitly shows 'if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90)' with a debug comment 'using single &', indicating the student wrote this intentionally but may not understand the semantic difference.

evidence.note: Single & operator used instead of && in boolean condition. The debug message confirms this was intentional but suggests the student may be testing without full understanding of the operator's true function.

misconceptions.name: Submitted wrong solution / wrong problem implementation
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. The submission demonstrates a fundamental misalignment between assignment requirements and submission.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either submitted the wrong file, copied code from a different assignment, or misunderstood which problem needed to be solved.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Carefully read the assignment specification before writing code. Ensure the submitted solution directly addresses the stated problem (grade calculator reading 0-100 and outputting A-F letter grades), not an unrelated problem.
symptoms: Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of something appropriate for a grade calculator
First half of code calculates distance using Math.sqrt, x1, y1, x2, y2 variables
No input prompts for reading a grade
No output of letter grades (A, B, C, D, F)
Grade logic appears only as a brief hardcoded example at the end
misconceptions.root_cause: Either accidental submission of wrong file, copy-paste error from a previous assignment, or fundamental misreading of the assignment specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Reread the Q3 specification carefully. Create a new program that: (1) reads a numeric grade as input, (2) uses if/else-if/else statements to check ranges 90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, <60, and (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Range checking with compound boolean expressions
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty: the submitted code solves an entirely different problem with different variable names, different calculation logic, and different I/O operations. This is not a partial solution or variation on the grade calculator.

evidence.note: Class solves distance calculation problem, not grade calculator. Wrong assignment submitted.
Calculates and outputs distance between points, not letter grade. Completely unrelated to grade problem.
